segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṃghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Great Wood, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.

segments.pli: dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya bhikkhusaṃghañca.
segments.en: And most of the deities from ten solar systems had gathered to see the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants.

segments.pli: Atha kho catunnaṃ suddhāvāsakāyikānaṃ devatānaṃ etadahosi:
segments.en: Then four deities of the Pure Abodes, aware of what was happening, thought:

segments.pli: “ayaṃ kho bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṃghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;
dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya bhikkhusaṃghañca.
Yannūna mayampi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike paccekaṃ gāthaṃ bhāseyyāmā”ti.
segments.en: “Why don’t we go to the Buddha and each recite a verse in his presence?”

segments.pli: Atha kho tā devatā seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—suddhāvāsesu devesu antarahitā bhagavato purato pāturahesuṃ.
segments.en: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the Pure Abodes and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

segments.pli: Atha kho tā devatā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: They bowed to the Buddha and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Standing to one side, one deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
“There’s a great congregation in the woods,
a host of gods have assembled.
We’ve come to this righteous congregation

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
“The mendicants there are immersed in samādhi,
they’ve straightened out their own minds.
Like a charioteer who has taken the reins,
the astute ones protect their senses.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
“Having cut the stake and cut the bar,
they’re unstirred, with boundary pillar uprooted.
the young dragons tamed by the seer.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
“Anyone who has gone to the Buddha for refuge
won’t go to a plane of loss.
After giving up this human body,
they swell the hosts of gods.”
Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

segments.pli: “yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, dasasu lokadhātūsu devatā sannipatitā honti, tathāgataṃ dassanāya bhikkhusaṃghañca.
segments.en: “Mendicants, most of the deities from ten solar systems have gathered to see the Realized One and the mendicant Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamāyeva devatā sannipatitā ahesuṃ seyyathāpi mayhaṃ etarahi.
segments.en: The Buddhas of the past had, and the Buddhas of the future will have, gatherings of deities that are at most like the gathering for me now.

segments.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamāyeva devatā sannipatitā bhavissanti seyyathāpi mayhaṃ etarahi.

segments.en: I shall declare the names of the heavenly hosts;
I shall extol the names of the heavenly hosts;
I shall teach the names of the heavenly hosts.
Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

They rejoice with all the spirits,

suttaplex.blurb: When deities from all realms gather in homage to the Buddha, he gives a series of verses describing them. These verses, which are commonly chanted in Theravadin countries, give one of the most detailed descriptions of the deities worshiped at the the time of the Buddha.
